newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - Jan 29.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - Jan 29.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Wednesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
BUSINESS DAY

- The government has announced a timetable for finding a strategic equity partner for South African Airways SAA.CN, a foreign equity partner for the Airports Company and for the privatisation of state-owned Sun Air.
- Details of how security policemen burned the bodies of anti-apartheid activists in the 1980s were released at a news conference held by the "truth commission".

- The Gauteng housing and land affairs department is to introduce new housing legislation this year, paving the way for a development fund. Around two billion rand in private sector money is already under negotiation.
- Three-quarters of South Africa's chartered accountants leave the country soon after qualifying and only about a third of them return, according to research by auditing firm Deloitte and Touche.
BUSINESS REPORT
- The average rate of consumer price inflation fell to a 24-year low of 7.4 percent last year, despite rising to 9.4 percent last month, the Central Statistical Service (CSS) said.

- Anglo American and its foreign minerals division Minorco have emerged as the leading contender in Brazil's plans to sell a controlling interest in Companhia Vale do Rio (CRVD), the country's largest mining company, Brazilian sources said.
- Gentyre, the tyre manufacturing group, is believed to have made a profit of 88 million rand for last week's sale of eight million shares in Tiger Wheels Holdings, industry sources said.
- The rand continued its relentless march forward yesterday, strengthening for the fifth day in a row to hit 4.5650 against the dollar in late trade from 4.5840 late on Monday.
SAKE BEELD
- South Africa's average consumer price inflation fell to a 24-year low last year, despite an increase in the inflation rate last month.
- Growth in money supply, as well as the rate of private sector credit extension, slowed more sharply in December than most economists expected.
- Chances are better than half-half that banks' prime lending rates will fall within six months, according to a survey of economists.
- Labour federation Cosatu is seriously considering a programme of mass action over proposed legislation on minimum employment standards.
THE STAR
- A group of former security policemen, including a retired general, have confessed to taking part in killing 10 Eastern Cape anti-apartheid leaders, including Steve Biko.
- The theft of an automatic cash-dispenser with about 22,000 rand from police headquarters in Pretoria revealed security gaps which had to be addressed urgently, police said.
- Almost 370,000 households in Johannesburg's Southern Metropolitan Council area who are in arrears on rates payments could face a legal battle to hold on to their properties.
